description.narrative: This will support the engagement of citizens of Tanzania in parliamentary issues.

receiver-org.narrative: Government of United Republic of Tanzania
Government of United Republic of Tanzania
Government of United Republic of Tanzania

description.narrative: 3.1 Number of best practices procedures identified and adopted by MP Constituency Offices (CO) 3.2 Increased public awareness and understanding of parliament role and activities 3.3 Number of stakeholder engagements by parliamentary party groups on issues of interest

comment.narrative: 1. Constituency Offices lack codified framework of operations including the respective roles of the MP, Parliament as well as that of the Ministry of Regional Administration and Local Government. 2. Outreach activities for the year 2016 had the following results: SabaSaba event had 45,753 visitors, 2017/2018 Budget session had 32,354 visitors, Bunge website has 612 subscribers while Facebook page had 35,531 followers, Instagram had 2,302 followers and Twitter had 2.4 million followers 3. No comprehensive communication plan exists 4. Data shows that the overwhelming majority (approximately 87%) require capacity building in the use of online and web-based tools .

1. Assessment conducted of current state of constituency offices with recommendations and action plan on implementing a system of offices, selection criteria for pilot offices established 2. Outreach events engage at least 5,000 citizens annually. At least 30% increase in number of visitors to the National Assembly Website database by 2020, 40% active subscribers for LSP mobile application, facebook, twitter and instagram pages. 3. At least 3 APPG is supported to develop & implement an action plan for broad public consultations in the areas of their interest upon which to recommend substantial amendments to bill or initiation of private motion. 4. At least 2 dialogue sessions organized

1. Assessment of the current state of constituency offices on going) 2. In 2018, SabaSaba event managed to reach out to 35,456 individuals with some estimated visitors of 2,000-2,500 per day, NaneNane event had a total of 24,525 visitors with an estimated 1,200 visitors per day and 2018/2019 Budget session=33,725. As of 24th Nov 2018, NA Facebook page had 51,301 followers and 49,459 likes, while the Twitter account has 871, 000 followers = 35% of the target. The NA IT department is currently working out to capture data for the website and Instagram page 3. One (1) dialogue session conducted by TWPG on issues related to GEWE/WRs 4. Effective management capacity of constituency offices enhanced among the trained COA in specific areas of improved strategic thinking, planning, data collection, record keeping and coherent liaison between the District Council, electorates and other stakeholders 5. Strengthened parliamentary awareness and aroused leadership desires among youth through the Youth Parliament Event which involved 60 students from 12 higher Institutions . Generally, the event enabled youths to learn various issues on parliamentary activities including understand the rules and procedures of the work of parliament, being aware of various challenges facing the society and argumentation. The Youth Parliamentary reviewed the Labour and Employment Bill, 2018, through which underscored the following: - That, the proposed bill grants female employees the right to breastfeed their children, they are now allowed to leave the office for a maximum of two hours at their convenience during working hours for breastfeeding, and - That, provisions of not less than 12 months contracts for professional and managerial cadre employees whereas previously these did not have a prescribed period.
6. APNAC engaged with Administration and Local Government Committee on the National Anti- Corruption Strategy and Action Plan (NACSAP, 2017-2022) as a result, the committee recognized APNAC as an important stakeholder in fighting against graft.
7. Following the capacity building training conducted by APNAC to the Committee on Administration and Local Government Affairs, it has led for the positive influence of APNAC towards the committee’s final report to the parliament. ‘In its report to the parliament on 7th February 2019, page 34 of the report, the Committee on Administration and Local Government Affairs recommended for a serious uptake and implementation of the NACSAP III strategy including allocation of financial resources for effective anti-corruption campaign.
8. TAPAFE engaged with Land, Natural Resources and Tourism Committee on issues of wildlife protection and environmental conservation, gaps in the existing law identified to be incorporated in the forthcoming Committee report
9. In addition, TAPAFE Industries, Trade and Environment Committee moved an amendment on renewable energy policy to allow production and distribution of renewable energy below 1MG by small scale and medium enterprises
10. TAPAFE also moved a successful bill on VAT exemption for solar energy investments which is resulting into a declined price of solar energy. Thus, emergent of private companies which helps to reach off grid rural communities with affordable solar power energy in the Country
11. While the TYPG, had interactions with the Parliamentary Committee for Constitutional and Legal Affairs on implementation of the Youth Development Policy of 2007 and the Youth Council of Tanzania Act No. 12 of 2015
12. TYPG interacted with the Constitutional and Legal Affairs committee on the Youth Development Fund. Previously the fund had much focus on the micro credit institutions like SACCOS ignoring the potential that lies with support to youth. As a result, TYPG influence legislation for the inclusion of youth focused support as a strategy for increased employment opportunities for youth. As such, an amendment of the Local Government Finance Act, cap 290 was tabled which proposed that 10% of the local government own sources to be allocated as loans for women 40%, youth 40% and people with disability 20%.

1. Support to at least 15 constituencies/districts based on assessment recommendations. Practical Best practices identified emanating form the piloted constituencies 2. SabaSaba event=77,000 visitors, 2018/2019 Budget session=37,000 visitors, Bunge website=1500 subscribers while Facebook page=38,000 followers, Instagram 2,700=followers and Twitter=2.6 million followers. 100 active subscribers for LSP mobile application 3. At least 5 stakeholder engagement conducted by APPGs 4. At least 4 dialogue sessions organized

1. Best practices of the Constituency offices identified awaiting for pilot exercise 2. SabaSaba exhibition=36,400 visitors in which 56% of them were male and 44 female, Facebook and Twitter accounts have continued to remain effective, whereby Facebook account has a total 53,901 followers, Twitter account has 144,000 followers, tweets 1653 and 1,066 likes, Number of visitors to the National Assembly=45000. 3. One (1) stakeholder engagement has been conducted between APNAC and PCCB. A consultative meeting with PCCB took place focusing on the status of the implementation of UNCAC, in which the following action points emerged 4. One (1) dialogue sessions organized between CSOs and the parliamentary committees

- Support is provided to Identify best practices and documentation including dissemination to the NA for adoption and at least 20% of the MCO adopt and implement the best practices - Support is provided to increased public awareness and understanding of Parliament role to at least 165,150 through Saba Saba, 2019/2020 Budget session, Bunge website, Facebook page, Instagram, and Twitter followers, while others are expected to subscribe for LSP mobile application -At least 6 stakeholder engagement conducted by APPGs

MP Constituency Offices Best practices documented and circulated to the NA for adoption Some of the recommendations include the following: - Enactment of Act of Parliament and regulations to provide for establishment and management of constituency offices, -The Clerk of the National Assembly should provide overall coordination while the LGAs should be responsible for daily operations, - The Clerk of the National Assembly should set standards and qualifications for constituency office staff, - The Clerk of the National Assembly should set and provide salaries for constituency office staff, and - The respective LGAs should be responsible for equipment, furniture, and utilities for the constituency offices. - Project facilitated about 286,000 Twitter, 56,003 Facebook, 700,000 Website, and the Instagram page with 22,994 subscribers including 30,200 visitors to SabaSaba Exhibition. Additionally a new social media platform-Parliament YouTube Channel gained 6,930 subscribers. - Also about 4 stakeholder engagement conducted by APPGs (APNODE, APNAC and TAPAFE).

- At least 25% of MCOs adopt and implement the best practices; Standard procedures tested for operation of offices; Based on piloting, recommendations developed on standard format, policies, and procedures for constituency offices - Saba Saba event=81,000 visitors, 2018/2019 Budget session=42,000 visitors, Bunge website=3000 subscribers while Facebook page=45,000 followers, Instagram 3,000=followers and Twitter=3 million followers. 200 active subscribers for LSP mobile application - At least 7 stakeholder engagement conducted by APPGs
